body: I think that means Python is failing to find its own standard library. I'm not sure why that would happen, though.
For me it does not work for any python interpreter in a virtualenv. Is this reproducible or is it just me?
Does just starting the Python interpreter with `/absolute/path/to/env/bin/python` in a terminal work?
yes, seems to work fine
Hmm, that's bizarre. And does `/absolute/path/to/env/bin/python -m IPython` work to start IPython?
yes, works fine as well
:confused: That should be more or less equivalent to what the notebook is doing to launch that kernel. I'm not sure why Python would fail to start in one situation but not the other.
Could the env variable in the subprocess not be the same ?
That could be. Are you starting the notebook from a terminal, or some other way?
Yes simply `ipython notebook` in my terminal. I think knowing if it's just me or if you can reproduce that with a `virtualenv` would help a lot for debugging.
I've just tried with a virtualenv, and it works exactly as I'd expect. Have you tested with an actual virtualenv, or only with conda envs?

I use kernelspecs for conda envs as well, and haven't had an issue.

@cel4 can you start regular IPython this way?

```
/path/to/env/bin/python -m IPython
```
already checked that ;-) https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/7947#issuecomment-76999010
Sorry, not paying enough attention. I do use conda envs with kernelspecs regularly, so I'm not sure what would be different. Maybe check env variables?

Uff, something seems to be broken here...

I'm trying to troubleshoot the problem, but new weird errors coming up:

```
[I 08:53:26.102 NotebookApp] Using existing profile dir: '/Users/ch/.ipython/profile_default'

```

Where are those `/Users/ch/miniconda/envs/sci34/bin/python: No module named IPython`  messages raised?

`/Users/ch/miniconda/envs/sci34/bin/python -m IPython --version`  prints `3.0.0`.
Can you run the server with `--debug`?

So it seems that if I start ipython in my activated `sci33` conda environment, everything works fine. However it does not seem to be possible to start this kernel when I'm in another conda or virtualenv environment.

It seems that the path to the site-packages is somehow screwed. I guess printing `site.getsitepackages()` would give some weird results. Yet, I understand too little from the kernel logic to debug that.

Here is the debug log. I didn't find anything suspicious.
https://gist.github.com/cel4/f1925979dcadfbfe9322
Can you share your environment variables (minus anything sensitive)? I suspect there might be something funny going on there.
Here you go: https://gist.github.com/cel4/ad8a35d452814a573108

I had some time for some further investigation: I only see this problem on my mac. I cannot reproduce it on a ubuntu box.

How to reproduce it (with miniconda):

The kernel environment:

```
conda create -n kernel python=2.7 ipython-notebook
source activate kernel
ipython kernelspec install-self --user
```

The notebook environment:

```
conda create -n ipy python=3.4 ipython-notebook
source activate ipy
ipython notebook
```

Is someone on OSX and has the time to check if it's reproducible, or just me?
This is still bugging me - anyone with a mac here who can try to reproduce this?

I have the same issue on my Mac. Using Anaconda 3.4 as default environment, trying to use a Python 2.7 from a conda environment as a kernel.

```
Could not find platform independent libraries <prefix>
Could not find platform dependent libraries <exec_prefix>
Consider setting $PYTHONHOME to <prefix>[:<exec_prefix>]
ImportError: No module named site
```

Okay, I nuked all my extra python kernels and installed new ones. This narrowed the problem down to this rather interesting observation:

When I start the notebook server in a `ipython-3.x` environment, everything works as expected. I can start start my self-defined `python2` and `python3` kernels.

When I start the notebook server in a `python-2.x` environment, I can start kernels in `py27` environments, but not kernels in any `py34` environment.

I get the `Could not find platform independent libraries <prefix>` error in this case.

But again, this issue does not seem to be reproducible on my ubuntu box. This already narrows the problem down to the point that it's not the environments themselves, but the fact that `python2` calls `python3`.

This is where I am stuck now.

This problem boils down to this:

``` python
import subprocess
from subprocess import Popen
cmd = [
    '/usr/local/bin/python',
    '-m', 'IPython.kernel',
    '-f', '/tmp/test_kernel.json'
]
p = Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
out, err = p.communicate()
print(err.decode("utf-8"))
```

-- `/Users/ch/miniconda/envs/sci34/bin/python: No module named IPython`
So you're telling it `/usr/local/bin/python` but it's trying to use `...envs/sci34/bin/python`? That's very strange.
What do you get from `file /usr/local/bin/python`?
And `ls -l /usr/local/bin/python`

I don't think it's a symlink issue. This here prints the expected path:

``` python
import subprocess
from subprocess import Popen
cmd = [
    '/usr/local/bin/python',
    '-c', 'import sys;print(sys.path)',
]
p = Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
out, err = p.communicate()
print(out.decode("utf-8"))
```

> ['', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools-17.0-py2.7.egg', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip-7.0.1-py2.7.egg', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python27.zip', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/plat-darwin', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/plat-mac', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/plat-mac/lib-scriptpackages', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/lib-tk', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/lib-old', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/lib-dynload', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages', '/usr/local/Cellar/python/2.7.10/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/gtk-2.0', '/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages']

`$ file /usr/local/bin/python` --> `/usr/local/bin/python: Mach-O 64-bit executable x86_64`
`ls -l /usr/local/bin/python` -->  `4 lrwxr-xr-x 1 ch admin 34 Jun  5 22:03 /usr/local/bin/python -> ../Cellar/python/2.7.10/bin/python`
Then I'm completely mystified. The error message you showed above is clearly coming from a different interpreter.

I have this problem on Mac OSX 10.9.5 and have a bit more information:  I get the error if I start the ipython notebook within the python 2.7 (non)environment, and I DON'T get the error if I start in the python3 environment.  I generate the error by opening the notebook and switching the kernel from within the notebook.  I have no PYTHONHOME env variable set .  This definitely seems like an environment issue.

Below is the full context.  I installed Anaconda-2.2.0-MacOSX-x86_64.pkg (having previously `mv anaconda oldconda`) . 


All is good under the python3 environment !  This is really going to confuse new users of ipynb .
